messages: f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (11:50): I finally found a solution to allow me to stream olympics from NBCs website, even though I'm not in the USA! :-)
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (11:51): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: which is? proxy? ?:)
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (11:52): I forward all connections using ssh through my web server which is in the USA
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (11:52): using: ssh -D 8080 -fN lachy.id.au  - and then setting my setting the SOCKS proxy in my browser to localhost 8080
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (11:53): http://ubuntu-tutorials.com/2008/06/18/tunnel-web-and-dns-traffic-over-ssh/
150ca666565bfcb850b2e2ee3c0f0c64 (11:55): there are no australian sites that offer internet feeds of the ollympics?
150ca666565bfcb850b2e2ee3c0f0c64 (11:55): perhaps http://www.cbc.ca/olympics/ would work better?
150ca666565bfcb850b2e2ee3c0f0c64 (11:56): oh, I forgot you're in norway
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:58): well my 1.5TB disk just started makin horrific noises
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:58): so i guess it's time to get a drobo

f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (11:58): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: i'm IP restricted from BBC news covereage, even though I am in the UK http://www.flickr.com/photos f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678/2753042810/
150ca666565bfcb850b2e2ee3c0f0c64 (12:00): I guess the broadcasters are forced to implement some sort of geographical restrictions
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:00): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/source-whatwg is 404
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (12:00): 150ca666565bfcb850b2e2ee3c0f0c64: forced by "exclusive deals" and greed
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:01): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: yeah, it's only not 404 while i'm running the gen script
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:01): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: the markup just had <dfncode> or something along those lines
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:01): no embedded nulls or anything

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:06): 150ca666565bfcb850b2e2ee3c0f0c64, yahoo7.com.au/Olympics has streaming, but I need access to server in Australia that I can tunnel through. I would prefer that, cause that only requires flash. I had to install silverlight to watch NBC, and I wish I didn't
150ca666565bfcb850b2e2ee3c0f0c64 (12:06): no norwegian sites?
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (12:07): is there is a flickr or youtube of short mp3 clips, so i can embed sound into my blog with (urg) flash (fall back to <audio> would be a plus)
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:07): not that I know of. But even if they did, they would have norwegian commentary, not english
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:07): there is also SOPCast, which has live streaming, but that only seems to have a chinese language stream
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:08): and its windows only, so I can only run it in virtual machine
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:10): ok, drobo purchased
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:10): i'm fed up of disks dying all the time, hopefully this will make it a non-issue
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:10): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, I was thinking about getting myself a drobo too
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:11): they seem pretty sweet
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:11): I don't have problem with disks dying, but I am running out of storage space, so I need an economical solution that is cheaper to setup than a RAID
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:15): can't you just buy a new disk and add it to the usb bus?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:16): my HFS+ filesystem holding my real-world test data and Time Machine backups just died
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:16): wishes HFS+ were more robust
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:16): I guess next time I should put the real-world data on a disk image instead of stressing the catalog file of the concrete fs
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:17): i made a point of not putting anything but my time machine backups on the time machine drive
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:17): I already have 2 external 1TB drives
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:17): (that's the one that just started making weird high pitches screeching noises)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:17): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: probably a good idea
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:17): (i just turned it off without checking if it was ok)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:18): (don't want to cause it to fail before i have something to replace it)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:18): my Time Machine disk never fills up, because HFS+ dies first and I have to restart Time Machine history
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:20): my 1.5TB disk was down to a few dozen GB
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:20): but unrelated to that i've had hell getting it to work over the network
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:21): I have high hopes for zfs
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:21): my disk failures have always sounded very hardware-related
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:21): i had a dell laptop once whose motherboard had a bug that was actually destroying hard disks
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:22): and my mac mini has had two disks die on it (both maxtor)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:22): (including this latest one)

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:23): my plan once i have the drobo is to get spinrite and put it on an old pc i have lying around and see if i can get the dead maxtor 750GB disk and the potentially dead maxtor 1.5TB disk up and working again
150ca666565bfcb850b2e2ee3c0f0c64 (12:23): can't recall ever suffering from a hard drive failure
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:23): and if so, use them as an external disk for my girlfriend's timemachine instead of going over the network
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:24): anyway, bed time first
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:25): btw anyone know why <script src=""> doesn't support javascript: URLs? (zcorpan sent mail late last year about it)
150ca666565bfcb850b2e2ee3c0f0c64 (12:28): does it not work in gecko?
150ca666565bfcb850b2e2ee3c0f0c64 (12:28): would expect it o
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:29): it does nothing

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:30): http://software.hixie.ch/utilities/js/live-dom-viewer/?%3C!DOCTYPE%20html%3E...%3Cscript%20src%3D%22javascript%3Aalert(%27test%27)%3B%27test%27%22%3E%3C%2Fscript%3E
150ca666565bfcb850b2e2ee3c0f0c64 (12:31): well, "alert" isn't valid JS
150ca666565bfcb850b2e2ee3c0f0c64 (12:32): that reutns alert.toString()
150ca666565bfcb850b2e2ee3c0f0c64 (12:32): which would justredefine alert
150ca666565bfcb850b2e2ee3c0f0c64 (12:32): ...with invalid JS code
150ca666565bfcb850b2e2ee3c0f0c64 (12:32): nevermind

ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (12:38): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: Do you have a view on whether, if RDFa in XHTML becomes a Recommendation (currently it's CR), it would be conforming with HTML5 to use its elements and attributes in an XML document also using the new RDFa attributes, which are also in http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml ( http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/CR-rdfa-syntax-20080620/ ) ?
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (12:38): or are these drafts fundamentally incompatible?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:39): sorry i don't quite follow the question

ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (12:40): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: I guess it boils down to: if some elements and attributes are placed into the HTML namespace by another W3C recommendation, can they be used in an XML document also using elements and attributes in the HTML namespace which are defined by HTML5?
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (12:42): Would that break document conformance with HTML5, for instance?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:42): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: I'm unable to reproduce the dtcode bug
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:43): ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee, it would

ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (12:44): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: Would it break conformance in a different way than (for example) including some elements in a completely different namespace (I dunno, MusicML or something) would?

ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (12:45): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: i.e. would it have the same relationship to HTML5 as the XML documents include XHTML and MathML do to XHTML 1.0? http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/#well-formed
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (12:45): *as XML documents that include
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:45): ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee: as implemented, they both get the same type of error message
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:46): interestingly, my "eRDF5" trial balloon got Warnocked, even though a couple of people had tried to stir discussion about RDFao
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:47): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: oops. I can reproduce the dtcode thing now
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:47): will investigate
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (12:48): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: Thanks.

c4c52ee28b65ac033f57ce478087cfd1 (13:00): does anyone know what a browser is supposed to do when (in an xhr response) it receives data ending with a partial unicode character -- should it trigger a readystate 3 with only the last complete character?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:01): it should simply try to decode it
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:01): the partial character will turn into U+FFFD
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:02): c4c52ee28b65ac033f57ce478087cfd1: do you mean really ending or the first buffer containing a partial character with potentially more data coming up?
c4c52ee28b65ac033f57ce478087cfd1 (13:02): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9, actually, I'm curious about both cases
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:03): same for both
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:03): ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee: it has the same conformance status as web forms 2 vs html4
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:03): ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee: using it would be conforming to the spec that makes up those attributes, but not to html5 proper

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:03): c4c52ee28b65ac033f57ce478087cfd1: if the stream ends, I'd do what edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e said. If the stream doesn't end, I'd hold onto the partial character expecting more data and behave as if that character hadn't yet been received as far as scripts go
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (13:04): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: That seems a reasonable answer. :) Thanks.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:04): ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee: it doesn't matter what the namespace is, though
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:04): ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee: from the point of view of conformance

c4c52ee28b65ac033f57ce478087cfd1 (13:04): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e, how could the web work at all if it turned it into a U+FFFD character? sometimes unicode characters get split into two seperate packets, and half of the character might come through before the other half
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (13:04): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: okay

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:05): c4c52ee28b65ac033f57ce478087cfd1: that is, I'd expect the partial character stay inside the decoder and the decoder not outputting more data until it has at least one complete character to output
c4c52ee28b65ac033f57ce478087cfd1 (13:05): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9, that makes sense

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:05): ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee: i mean, the spec could say it's the xhtml namespace, or that it's the foobar namespace, html5 doesn't care, html5 just cares about "metadata elements" and "phrasing elements" and so on, the categories

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:08): fwiw, I think RDFa could be mostly harmless if it used full URIs instead of CURIEs and, therefore, didn't need to know the namespace mapping context at each node
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:08): I'm strongly opposed to importing any CURIE or other qnames-in-content stuff into HTML5
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:09): RDFa would be mostly harmless in the same way that products in sky mall magazines are mostly harmless

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:10): they're solving a problem that people think they have when they're stuck 30,000ft up for 12 hours, but when they get down to earth, they don't find it actually fits in with their workflow
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:12): i should totally make a sky mall catalogue of web standards
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:14): I'd be interested to know how RDFa ended up in the HTML WG charter
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:15): probably similar to how the word XForms ended up there
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:16): or ITS
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:17): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: dtcode issue fixed
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:17): cool, what was it?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:18): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: no longer saying that <dtcode> cannot be mapped to XML
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:18): right i mean what was the source of the bug? :-)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:19): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: I had forgotten the NCName check and only checked for customness when name policy was allowing XML violations
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:40): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, insertAdjacentHTML is not an attribute
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:40): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, the sentence outerHTML and insertAdjacentHTML attributes should probably say "members"
